p: The large pine weevil Hylobius abietis (L.) (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) is an economically important species causing damage in coniferous plantations in Europe and Asia [ 1, 2]. Its pest status is a consequence of modern silvicultural practices that are largely based on clearcuttings and reforestation. Sanitation logging in the areas of recent bark beetle outbreaks in Europe has magnified the amount of available breeding substrate [ 3, 4, 5, 6]. In the Czech Republic, damage by the large pine weevil has doubled every year since 2014 [ 7] and H. abietis was identified as the major threat to successful reforestation in central and northern Europe [ 8, 9].
